problem.p: An L shaped block of mass m2 and a box of mass m1 \( (m_2 > m_1) \) are connected by a horizontal spring of spring constant k. The spring is compressed a distance X with respect to its equilibrium length and a rope is used to hold the block and the box motionless together as shown in the figure 1. There is friction between the block and the box but there is no friction between the L shaped block and the ground.
When the rope is cut the spring expands to recover its equilibrium position. As a result, the box moves to the left and the L-shaped box to the right as shown in figure 2.

Which of the following statements accurately describes the linear momentum of the block-box-spring system during the time interval that starts at the instant at which the rope is cut, and ends at the instant at which the box is moving with speed V1 and the block is moving with V2?

choice.p: The linear momentum of the block-box-spring system must be conserved.
The linear momentum of the block-box-spring system is not conserved.
The linear momentum of the block-box-spring system is conserved only when m1 = m2.

problem.p: My answer to part 1 is justified because:

choicegroup.choice: The spring’s potential energy is completely converted to kinetic energy.
Both the spring and the friction act equally on the box and the block.
The friction removes momentum from the system.
The process is essentially an elastic collision.

problem.p: Which of the following statements accurately describes the mechanical energy of the block-box-spring system during the time interval that starts at the instant at which the rope is cut, and ends at the instant at which the box is moving with speed V1 and the block is moving with V2?

choice.p: The mechanical energy of the block-box-spring system must be conserved.
The mechanical energy of the block-box-spring system is not conserved.>
The mechanical energy of the block-box-spring system is only conserved when m1 = m2.

problem.p: My answer to part 3 is justified because:

choicegroup.choice: Both the spring and the friction act equally on the box and the block.
The spring’s potential energy is completely converted to kinetic energy.
The friction removes mechanical energy from the system.
The process is essentially an elastic collision.
